work.p: Portions of this manuscript are similar to lines in a manuscript poem titled "Pictures," first published posthumously in 1925. The first several lines of "Pictures" were revised and first published as "My Picture-Gallery" in The American in October 1880, but none of the lines from this manuscript were included.

titleStmt.title: Two scenes capriciously rising out
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive.

notesStmt.note: Portions of this manuscript are similar to lines in a manuscript poem titled "Pictures," first published posthumously in 1925. Other lines have no known relationship to Whitman's published work.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: I do not relegate you
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

lg.l:
(Two pictures scenes
capriciously rising out
of the past,

In one the Olympic games, the
naked boxers boxing, and
the runners running,

In another, pupils collect in the
gardens of Athens, waiting their favorite
masters,

Young men crowded in groups
listen to the elder ones or
harangue each other

Elsewhere single fingures figures
lean against pillars or within
recesses, studying manuscripts;)
